{"uri": "8183029794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "06:23:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T06:23:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T06:23:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/sports/shohei-ohtani-leads-dodgers-in-9-5-win-over-the-rockies/3438980/", "title": "Shohei Ohtani leads Dodgers in 9-5 win over the Rockies", "body": "Shohei Ohtani had three hits, James Paxton pitched seven smooth innings and the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Colorado Rockies 9-5 in the opener of a four-game series between the top and bottom teams in the NL West.\n\nShohei Ohtani had three hits, James Paxton pitched seven smooth innings and the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Colorado Rockies 9-5 on Monday night in the opener of a four-game series between the top and bottom teams in the NL West.\n\nMiguel Rojas and Jason Heyward also had three hits apiece for the first-place Dodgers, who finished with 14. Freddie Freeman walked five times, one shy of a major league record.\n\n\"Over the last few weeks, I know we haven't been swinging the way we wanted to, but it felt like the bats were getting better and better as each day went on,\" Freeman said. \"Today, we just kind of put it all together.\"\n\nOhtani doubled twice, drove in a run and had his third multi-hit performance in his past four games, a stretch in which he has seven hits in 15 at-bats. The two-time AL MVP entered second in the majors in extra-base hits, tied for fifth in hits and sixth in batting average.\n\nPaxton (7-1) permitted just one run and two hits in his longest outing of the season. He had a season-high eight strikeouts and walked only one in his first career start at hitter-friendly Coors Field.\n\n\"If you're thinking about it being Coors Field and the ball flying and you're worried about that, you're not focused on the pitch you're throwing,\" Paxton said. \"You can't be distracted by stuff like that.\"\n\nLos Angeles left 13 runners on base, equaling a season high.\n\nThe loss was the Rockies' sixth in their past eight games and 12th in 16 games in June. During that stretch, they've been outscored by a 109-66 margin.\n\nJacob Stallings, Greg Jones and Hunter Goodman homered for Colorado, which got four runs in the ninth inning off reliever J.P. Feyereisen. Jones' home run, which came as a pinch hitter in the ninth, was his first career hit.\n\nCal Quantrill (6-5) gave up seven hits and three earned runs in five innings. The 29-year-old right-hander entered 6-1 with a 1.91 ERA over his previous eight starts.\n\n\"They just make it hard,\" Quantrill said. \"If you get the first two guys out, they're going to make sure that that third guy is a tough out. There are some things I could have done better today, but on the whole, we battled. We just weren't able to make it happen.\"\n\nTRAINER'S ROOM\n\nDodgers: SS Mookie Betts (fractured left hand) was placed on the 10-day injured list, with manager Dave Roberts saying the 2018 AL MVP will miss roughly six to eight weeks. ... Los Angeles recalled OF Miguel Vargas from Triple-A Oklahoma City.\n\nRockies: Reinstated RHP Jake Bird (right elbow inflammation) and RHP Justin Lawrence (right shoulder strain) from the 15-day IL. ... Placed LHP Josh Rogers (rotator cuff strain) on the 15-day IL, retroactive to June 14. ... Optioned RHP Angel Chivilli to Double-A Hartford.\n\nUP NEXT\n\nDodgers RHP Walker Buehler (1-4, 4.64 ERA) pitches Tuesday against LHP Austin Gomber (1-4, 4.36).", "source": {"uri": Freddie Freeman walked five times, one shy of a major league record.\n\nOhtani doubled twice, drove in a run and had his third multi-hit performance in his past four games, a stretch in which he has seven hits in 15 at-bats. The two-time AL MVP entered second in the majors in extra-base hits, tied for fifth in hits and sixth in batting average.\n\nPaxton (7-1) permitted just one run and two hits in his longest outing of the season. He had a season-high eight strikeouts and walked only one.\n\nLos Angeles left 13 runners on base, equaling a season high.\n\nThe loss was the Rockies' sixth in their past eight games and 12th in 16 games in June. During that stretch, they've been outscored by a 109-66 margin.\n\nJacob Stallings, Greg Jones and Hunter Goodman homered for Colorado, which got four runs in the ninth off reliever J.P. Feyereisen. Jones' home run, which came as a pinch hitter in the ninth inning, was his first career hit.\n\nCal Quantrill (6-5) gave up seven hits and three earned runs in five innings. The 29-year-old right-hander entered 6-1 with a 1.91 ERA over his previous eight starts.\n\nTRAINER'S ROOM\n\nDodgers: SS Mookie Betts (fractured left hand) was placed on the 10-day injured list, with manager Dave Roberts saying the 2018 AL MVP will miss roughly six to eight weeks. ... Los Angeles recalled OF Miguel Vargas from Triple-A Oklahoma City.\n\nRockies: Reinstated RHP Jake Bird (right elbow inflammation) and RHP Justin Lawrence (right shoulder strain) from the 15-day IL. ... Placed LHP Josh Rogers (rotator cuff strain) on the 15-day IL, retroactive to June 14. ... Freddie Freeman walked five times, one shy of a major league record.\n\n\"Over the last few weeks, I know we haven't been swinging the way we wanted to, but it felt like the bats were getting better and better as each day went on,\" Freeman said. \"Today, we just kind of put it all together.\"\n\nOhtani doubled twice, drove in a run and had his third multi-hit performance in his past four games, a stretch in which he has seven hits in 15 at-bats. The two-time AL MVP entered second in the majors in extra-base hits, tied for fifth in hits and sixth in batting average.\n\nPaxton (7-1) permitted just one run and two hits in his longest outing of the season. He had a season-high eight strikeouts and walked only one in his first career start at hitter-friendly Coors Field.\n\n\"If you're thinking about it being Coors Field and the ball flying and you're worried about that, you're not focused on the pitch you're throwing,\" Paxton said. \"You can't be distracted by stuff like that.\"\n\nLos Angeles left 13 runners on base, equaling a season high.\n\nThe loss was the Rockies' sixth in their past eight games and 12th in 16 games in June. During that stretch, they've been outscored by a 109-66 margin.\n\nJacob Stallings, Greg Jones and Hunter Goodman homered for Colorado, which got four runs in the ninth inning off reliever J.P. Feyereisen. Jones' home run, which came as a pinch hitter in the ninth, was his first career hit.\n\nCal Quantrill (6-5) gave up seven hits and three earned runs in five innings. The 29-year-old right-hander entered 6-1 with a 1.91 ERA over his previous eight starts.\n\n\"They just make it hard,\" Quantrill said. \"If you get the first two guys out, they're going to make sure that that third guy is a tough out. There are some things I could have done better today, but on the whole, we battled. We just weren't able to make it happen.\"\n\nTRAINER'S ROOM\n\nDodgers: SS Mookie Betts (fractured left hand) was placed on the 10-day injured list, with manager Dave Roberts saying the 2018 AL MVP will miss roughly six to eight weeks. ... Placed LHP Josh Rogers (rotator cuff strain) on the 15-day IL, retroactive to June 14. ... Freddie Freeman walked five times, one shy of a major-league record.\n\n\"Over the last few weeks, I know we haven't been swinging the way we wanted to, but it felt like the bats were getting better and better as each day went on,\" Freeman said. \"Today, we just kind of put it all together.\"\n\nOhtani doubled twice, drove in a run, and had his third multi-hit performance in his past four games, a stretch in which he has seven hits in 15 at-bats. The two-time American League most valuable player entered the game second in the major leagues in extra-base hits, tied for fifth in hits, and sixth in batting average.\n\nPaxton (7-1) permitted just one run and two hits in his longest outing of the season. He had a season-high eight strikeouts and walked only one in his first career start at hitter-friendly Coors Field.\n\n\"If you're thinking about it being Coors Field and the ball flying and you're worried about that, you're not focused on the pitch you're throwing,\" Paxton said. \"You can't be distracted by stuff like that.\"\n\nLos Angeles left 13 runners on base, equaling its most this season.\n\nThe loss was the Rockies' sixth in their past eight games and 12th in 16 games in June. During that stretch, they've been outscored 109-66.\n\nJacob Stallings, Greg Jones, and Hunter Goodman homered for Colorado, which got four runs in the ninth inning off reliever J.P. Feyereisen. Jones' home run, which came as a pinch hitter in the ninth, was his first career hit.\n\nRockies starter Cal Quantrill (6-5) gave up three earned runs and seven hits in five innings. {"uri": "8182955335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "05:24:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T05:24:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T05:22:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://japannews.yomiuri.co.jp/sports/baseball/20240618-192845/", "title": "Shohei Ohtani and James Paxton Lead the Dodgers to a 9-5 Win over the Rockies", "body": "DENVER (AP) -- Shohei Ohtani had three hits, James Paxton pitched seven smooth innings and the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Colorado Rockies 9-5 on Monday night in the opener of a four-game series between the top and bottom teams in the NL West.\n\nMiguel Rojas and Jason Heyward also had three hits apiece for the first-place Dodgers, who finished with 14. Freddie Freeman walked five times, one shy of a major league record.\n\nOhtani doubled twice, drove in a run and had his third multi-hit performance in his past four games, a stretch in which he has seven hits in 15 at-bats. The two-time AL MVP entered second in the majors in extra-base hits, tied for fifth in hits and sixth in batting average.\n\nPaxton (7-1) permitted just one run and two hits in his longest outing of the season. He had a season-high eight strikeouts and walked only one.\n\nLos Angeles left 13 runners on base, equaling a season high.\n\nThe loss was the Rockies' sixth in their past eight games and 12th in 16 games in June. During that stretch, they've been outscored by a 109-66 margin.\n\nJacob Stallings, Greg Jones and Hunter Goodman homered for Colorado, which got four runs in the ninth off reliever J.P. Feyereisen. Jones' home run, which came as a pinch hitter in the ninth inning, was his first career hit.\n\nCal Quantrill (6-5) gave up seven hits and three earned runs in five innings. He has struggled to get started this season, however, as he is batting .108 and didn't hit his first home run until Friday night. The veteran is trying to keep perspective as he works through his struggles.\n\n\"I try to just take it day by day,\" Taylor said. \"I've definitely had my moments of frustration, but just trying to embrace the process and trust that my work is going to eventually come through for me.\"\n\nPaxton is having a bounce-back season, his first with the Dodgers, and will face the Rockies for the sixth time in his career. Freddie Freeman walked five times, one shy of a major league record.\n\nOhtani doubled twice, drove in a run and had his third multi-hit performance in his past four games, a stretch in which he has seven hits in 15 at-bats. The two-time AL MVP entered second in the majors in extra-base hits, tied for fifth in hits and sixth in batting average.\n\nPaxton (7-1) permitted just one run and two hits in his longest outing of the season. The Rockies have lost four of five.\n\nGavin Stone (8-2) gave up two runs and four hits, all singles, in 5 1/3 innings. He tied a season high with seven strikeouts, all swinging, walked two and hit a batter.\n\nLos Angeles Dodgers' Shohei Ohtani gestures as he circles the bases after hitting a solo home run off Colorado Rockies starting pitcher Ty Blach in the first inning of baseball game Thursday, June 20, 2024, in Denver. (AP Photo/David Zalubowski)\n\nStone recorded three strikeouts with his mid-90s fastball and two apiece with a curveball and a changeup. He is 7-1 with a 2.18 ERA in 10 starts since April 26.\n\nTeoscar Hern\u00e1ndez had three hits and scored a run, Freeman had two hits and Chris Taylor had two hits and two stolen bases. Freeman pulled up after reaching on an infield single in the ninth but remained in the game after a visit from manager David Roberts and a member of the training staff.\n\nMcMahon and Cave each had two of the Rockies\u00b4 six hits.\n\nOhtani\u00b4s homer to center field just got over the fence and the outstretched glove of Brenton Doyle, who collided with the fence at the 415-foot sign.\n\nREUNION DAY\n\nOhtani will face the Los Angeles Angels in a two-game series at Dodger Stadium beginning Friday, a first since he signed a 10-year, $700 million free-agent deal with the crosstown Dodgers after six seasons with the Angels.\n\n\"I think he is grateful for his time in Anaheim, grateful for the fans,\" manager Dave Roberts said. \"I think he wants to get it over with and help the Dodgers win.\"\n\nTRAINER\u00b4S ROOM\n\nDodgers: LHP Clayton Kershaw (offseason shoulder surgery) struck out five in three innings of his first rehab appearance Wednesday for Class A Rancho Cucamonga. Teo, he keeps coming up with big hits. That inning, certainly, the results showed the fight, the compete.\"\n\nHeyward's fourth career grand slam came off Tyler Kinley and followed walks by Andy Pages and Miguel Vargas around a single by Miguel Rojas. I was like, 'Come on, squeak in, squeak in.' I honestly feel like we got rewarded for our process\" in the ninth.\n\nShohei Ohtani, who had a 476-foot homer in the fifth, singled off Victor Vodnik (1-1) before Will Smith struck out looking after attempting to step out of the batter's box on a 3-2 pitch.\n\nAfter a wild pitch, Freddie Freeman received an intentional walk, his sixth walk in the last two games, bringing up Hernandez. Hernandez took a half-swing at a 1-2 fastball and first base umpire Lance Barksdale ruled that Hernandez did not commit. Colorado manager Bud Black argued the call and was ejected.\n\nOn the next pitch, Hernandez hit his 18th home to make it 11-9.\n\nAfter Hernandez's ball cleared the wall, Colorado right field Jake Cave immediately took a few steps toward Barksdale and began yelling. Rockies' second baseman Alan Trejo stepped between Cave and Barksdale after the inning ended.\n\n\"It was close,\" Hernandez said. \"You can call it either way and it will be fine. When Jason hit the grand slam and turning the lineup over to Ohtani, you know something was going to happen. I just wanted to get a good pitch hit to tie the game. And he did swing. It was the first time the 29-yeaer-old right-hander allowed more than three earned runs since returning to the rotation May 6 after missing the 2023 season because of Tommy John surgery. He struck out two and walked one.\n\nPages also homered for the Dodgers, who have won four of five and are 73-32 against Colorado since 2018. But awesome.\"\n\nTRAINER'S ROOM\n\nDodgers: LHP Clayton Kershaw (shoulder surgery) is scheduled to pitch three innings for Class A Rancho Cucamonga on Wednesday in his first rehab start of the season. \"He's doing fantastic,\" manager Dave Roberts said, adding that Kershaw will follow the natural progression of two or three more rehab starts \"and then we'll see where we are at.\"\n\nRockies: DH/OF Charlie Blackmon (right hamstring tightness) was removed after suffering his injury while running the bases in the first. ... The game was three outs away from being over.\n\nOf course, that's when they finally came alive.\n\nThe Dodgers, behind two massive home runs from Jayson Heyward and Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez, pulled off a ridiculous rally to claim an 11-9 win over the Colorado Rockies. They put up seven runs in the ninth inning alone to escape with the win.\n\nFirst, after loading up the bases in the ninth inning, it was Heyward who drilled a grand slam with his deep shot off the right field foul pole. That suddenly cut the deficit down to just a single run.\n\nThen, with two outs and two strikes on him, Hern\u00e1ndez followed suit. He hit a three-run home run himself to put the Dodgers in the lead for the first time all night.\n\nFrom there, the Dodgers quickly shut down the Rockies in the bottom of the inning to officially grab the win.\n\nThe Dodgers entered the ninth inning with four runs on the board, thanks largely to star Shohei Ohtani. He had two hits, two RBI and a deep solo home run in the sixth inning -- which traveled a season-record 476 feet into center field off of Rockies pitcher Austin Gomber.\n\nOhtani now has 20 home runs and 91 hits and 49 RBI on the year.\n\nThe win marked the Dodgers' fourth in their last five games and second straight over the Rockies. They hold a 46-29 record, which is good for a massive lead in the NL West, heading into Wednesday's game in Denver -- which will be the third in the four-game series against the Rockies.\n\nThe Rockies, on the other hand, sit in last in the division standings and have now lost seven of their last nine games. Freddie Freeman also had two hits for the Dodgers.\n\nLos Angeles' Bobby Miller made his first start since April 10 after spending more than two months on the injured list because of inflammation in his right shoulder.\n\nAfter Toglia hit a three-run homer off Miller in the first inning, the Dodgers took a 4-3 lead in the second on Ohtani's three-run double and Freeman's RBI single.\n\nJason Heyward, who hit a grand slam to start Los Angeles' seven-run ninth inning Tuesday night, doubled home two runs in the fifth off Rockies starter Ryan Feltner.\n\nMiller went 6 1/3 innings - his longest outing this year - but was denied the victory when Colorado scored twice in the seventh.\n\nTRAINER'S ROOM\n\nDodgers: Placed RHP Walker Buehler on the 15-day injured list because of inflammation in his right hip. Hernandez took a half-swing at a 1-2 fastball and first base umpire Lance Barksdale ruled that Hernandez did not commit. Colorado manager Bud Black argued the call and was ejected.\n\nOn the next pitch, Hernandez hit his 18th home to make it 11-9.\n\nAfter Hernandez's ball cleared the wall, Colorado right field Jake Cave immediately took a few steps toward Barksdale and began yelling. Rockies' second baseman Alan Trejo stepped between Cave and Barksdale after the inning ended.\n\n\"It was close,\" Hernandez said. \"You can call it either way and it will be fine. When Jason hit the grand slam and turning the lineup over to Ohtani, you know something was going to happen. I just wanted to get a good pitch hit to tie the game. I put a little extra and it went over the fence. I knew as soon as I hit. It was great, especially because it put the team ahead.\"\n\nEvan Phillips got the only batter he faced, Hunter Goodman, with a runner on second to record his 11th save in as many chances. And he did swing. It's a big game, it's one of the best teams in baseball and we're battling with them.\n\n\"That game's won on that swing, That's a swing-and-miss, the game's won, and we beat the Los Angeles Dodgers.\"\n\nElehuris Montero and Brenton Doyle homered for the Rockies, who scored four runs in the first and twice led by five runs.\n\nDoyle added three singles for his first career four-hit game, scored twice, and made a diving catch of Ohtani's line drive to right-center field with runners on first and second and two outs in the seventh inning, preserving an 8-4 lead.\n\nDodgers starter Walker Buehler gave up eight hits and seven runs in four innings. It was the first time the 29-yeaer-old right-hander allowed more than three earned runs since returning to the rotation May 6 after missing the 2023 season because of Tommy John surgery. He struck out two and walked one.\n\nPages also homered for the Dodgers, who have won four of five and are 73-32 against Colorado since 2018. The Rockies have lost five of six.\n\nMichael Petersen (1-0) worked two innings of relief and struck out two in his major league debut.\n\n\"It was crazy,\" said Petersen, whose relatives were in attendance. \"You can't feel anything. Heyward's fourth homer of the season hit the right field foul pole and pulled the Dodgers within 9-8 with one out in the inning after they trailed 7-2 after four.\n\n\"I wasn't sure if it was going to stay fair or not,\" said Heyward, who hit an inside slider, \"It's Colorado, so maybe that helped it straighten out a little bit. I was like, 'Come on, squeak in, squeak in.' I honestly feel like we got rewarded for our process\" in the ninth.\n\nShohei Ohtani, who had a 476-foot homer in the fifth, singled off Victor Vodnik (1-1) before Will Smith struck out looking after attempting to step out of the batter's box on a 3-2 pitch.\n\nAfter a wild pitch, Freddie Freeman received an intentional walk, his sixth walk in the last two games, bringing up Hernandez. Hernandez took a half-swing at a 1-2 fastball and first base umpire Lance Barksdale ruled that Hernandez did not commit. Colorado manager Bud Black argued the call and was ejected.\n\nOn the next pitch, Hernandez hit his 18th home to make it 11-9.\n\nAfter Hernandez's ball cleared the wall, Colorado right field Jake Cave immediately took a few steps toward Barksdale and began yelling. Rockies' second baseman Alan Trejo stepped between Cave and Barksdale after the inning ended.\n\n\"It was close,\" Hernandez said. \"You can call it either way and it will be fine. It was great, especially because it put the team ahead.\"\n\nEvan Phillips got the only batter he faced, Hunter Goodman, with a runner on second to record his 11th save in as many chances. Cave, the on-deck hitter, was restrained by bench Mike Redmond as he attempted to reach Barksdale after the game ended.\n\n\"When I'm running in (before the last of the ninth), he looks me right in the face and goes, 'Cave, it's not even close,'\" Cave said. \"Everybody in the world could see it was at least close. And he did swing. It's a big game, it's one of the best teams in baseball and we're battling with them.\n\n\"That game's won on that swing, That's a swing-and-miss, the game's won, and we beat the Los Angeles Dodgers.\"\n\nElehuris Montero and Brenton Doyle homered for the Rockies, who scored four runs in the first and twice led by five runs.\n\nDoyle added three singles for his first career four-hit game, scored twice, and made a diving catch of Ohtani's line drive to right-center field with runners on first and second and two outs in the seventh inning, preserving an 8-4 lead.\n\nDodgers starter Walker Buehler gave up eight hits and seven runs in four innings. It was the first time the 29-yeaer-old right-hander allowed more than three earned runs since returning to the rotation May 6 after missing the 2023 season because of Tommy John surgery. He struck out two and walked one.\n\nPages also homered for the Dodgers, who have won four of five and are 73-32 against Colorado since 2018. The Rockies have lost five of six.\n\nMichael Petersen (1-0) worked two innings of relief and struck out two in his major league debut.\n\n\"It was crazy,\" said Petersen, whose relatives were in attendance. \"You can't feel anything. It's like your first date, you are tripping over stuff. But awesome.\"\n\nTRAINER'S ROOM\n\nDodgers: LHP Clayton Kershaw (shoulder surgery) is scheduled to pitch three innings for Class A Rancho Cucamonga on Wednesday in his first rehab start of the season. \"He's doing fantastic,\" manager Dave Roberts said, adding that Kershaw will follow the natural progression of two or three more rehab starts \"and then we'll see where we are at.\"\n\nRockies: DH/OF Charlie Blackmon (right hamstring tightness) was removed after suffering his injury while running the bases in the first. ... LHP Kyle Freeland (elbow strain) gave up two hits and two runs and struck out four in four innings of a rehab start for Triple-A Albuquerque on Tuesday and appears close to returning. ... 2B Brendan Rodgers (hamstring) did normal pregame work Tuesday and is expected to begin a rehab assignment on Thursday with an eye toward a weekend activation. ... OF Sean Bouchard (ankle) led off and was 1 for 3 with two walks as the DH for Albuquerque.\n\nNEXT UP\n\nDodgers RHP Bobby Miller (1-1, 5.40 ERA) will oppose Rockies RHP Ryan Feltner (1-6, 5.71) in the third game of a four-game series. Miller will make his fourth start, his first since April 10, after missing nine weeks with right shoulder inflammation. Freddie Freeman also had two hits for the Dodgers.\n\nLos Angeles' Bobby Miller made his first start since April 10 after spending more than two months on the injured list because of inflammation in his right shoulder.\n\nAfter Toglia hit a three-run homer off Miller in the first inning, the Dodgers took a 4-3 lead in the second on Ohtani's three-run double and Freeman's RBI single.\n\n\"The adrenaline was pretty high in the first inning, got a couple of quick outs and then a two-out walk,\" Miller said. \"(Toglia), I missed a fastball down the middle. I'd like to think if I throw it in a different spot I'd only let up two runs.\"\n\nJason Heyward, who hit a grand slam to start Los Angeles' seven-run ninth inning Tuesday night, doubled home two runs in the fifth off Rockies starter Ryan Feltner.\n\nMiller went 6 1/3 innings - his longest outing this year - but was denied the victory when Colorado scored twice in the seventh.\n\nDodgers: Placed RHP Walker Buehler on the 15-day injured list because of inflammation in his right hip. {"uri": "2024-06-395106701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:39:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:39:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:04:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://dodgerblue.com/dodgers-mlb-history-jason-heyward-grand-slam-teoscar-hernandez-home-run-rockies/2024/06/19/", "title": "Jason Heyward & Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez Combine To Help Dodgers Make MLB History", "body": "Bobby Miller Feeling 'Really Good' For Return To Dodgers Rotation\n\nThe Los Angeles Dodgers entered the ninth inning trailing by five runs on Tuesday night against the Colorado Rockies. It was a deficit the Dodgers hadn't overcome in nearly 70 years entering the final inning, but Jason Heyward and Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez helped them achieve a rare feat.\n\nHeyward pinch-hit for Chris Taylor and pulled a grand slam to right field that hit off the foul pole and cut the Dodgers' deficit to one run. The Rockies then turned to Victor Vodnik, who gave up a single to Shohei Ohtani and intentionally walked Freddie Freeman before striking out Will Smith.\n\nVodnik had the Rockies one strike away from hanging on for a win, and appeared to get that but first base umpire Lance Barksdale ruled Hern\u00e1ndez did not go around on his check-swing. Hern\u00e1ndez then drove the next pitch out to right-center field for a game-winning home run.\n\nHeyward's grand slam and Hern\u00e1ndez's home run helped the Dodgers make MLB history for the ninth inning.\n\nWhile the Rockies certainly left unhappy with the call that allowed Hern\u00e1ndez to stay alive in the count, they could have avoided the situation entirely by recording three outs before the Dodgers were in a position to make history and take the lead behind a furious rally.\n\nThe comeback was reminiscent of Andrew Toles hitting a go-ahead grand slam in the ninth inning of a 2016 game at Coors Field.\n\nDodgers comeback makes franchise history\n\nManager Dave Roberts was impressed with the way the team was able to climb back from such a steep deficit so late in the game to steal a victory away from the Rockies, which amounted to franchise history.\n\nTuesday's game represented the biggest ninth-inning comeback in Dodgers history since 1957 and their first time {"uri": "8185854127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:23:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:23:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:23:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.outkick.com/sports/dodgers-take-advantage-controversial-checked-swing-immediately-hit-game-winning-hr", "title": "Dodgers Take Advantage Of Controversial Call, Immediately Hit Game-Winning HR", "body": "It's been a rough week for the Los Angeles Dodgers. Though they sit in first place, well ahead of the rest of the National League West, the Dodgers lost superstar shortstop Mookie Betts for at least 6-8 weeks after he was hit in the hand by a 98mph fastball on Sunday.\n\nThat came one day after losing rookie phenom Yoshinobu Yamamoto for an undetermined amount of time with a strained rotator cuff. But if there's one thing the modern Dodgers have excelled at, it's building depth to sustain injury issues. And that depth was on full display in a crazy, wild, insane finish during Tuesday night's game in Denver against the Colorado Rockies. Oh, and they also benefited from a controversial no-call on a checked swing.\n\nAfter a rocky start from Walker Buehler, it seemed like the Rockies would cruise to an easy win. Even after a mammoth 476-foot home run from Shohei Ohtani.\n\nThe Rockies then got a remarkable diving catch from Brenton Doyle in center field to save two runs in the 7th inning, robbing Ohtani of a double into the gap.\n\nThey added on another run, taking a 9-4 lead into the top of the 9th inning. That's when things quickly went haywire.\n\nAndy Pages walked, Miguel Rojas hit a bloop single to center, and Miguel Vargas walked after a Kik\u00e9 Hernandez strikeout. That led to a Jason Heyward pinch-hit grand slam off the foul pole.\n\nThat made Shohei Ohtani the tying run at the plate, and he promptly banged a single the opposite way. A wild pitch, strikeout and intentional walk to Freddie Freeman put runners at first and second with two out. That's when the controversy started.\n\nTeoscar Hernandez appeared to have gone around on a 1-2 pitch, but first base umpire Lance Barksdale, to the despair of the Rockies bench, said he didn't go.\n\nThe very next pitch, Hernandez launched a three-run homer to right center field.\n\nThanks to the reprieve on the checked swing, the Dodgers were able to score seven runs in the ninth inning to win 11-9 after trailing 9-4 entering the inning. Only the Rockies.\n\nDebate over the checked swing seems to be pretty evenly split. The rule is open to interpretation, and while that type of checked swing is usually called a strike, it's a 50/50 call. Rockies fans think he went, Dodgers fans think he didn't.\n\nThe only opinion that mattered though, was Barksdale's, and it led directly to one of the most remarkable comebacks you'll ever see. The win pushed the Dodgers to 46-29 and cemented a commanding nine game lead over the second place Arizona Diamondbacks.\n\nLose Mookie Betts? Rely on Jason Heyward and Teoscar Hernandez to deliver. Lose Yoshinobu Yamamoto? Bobby Miller returns Wednesday. {"uri": "8182839995", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "03:35:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T03:35:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T03:34:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.truebluela.com/2024/6/17/24180543/james-paxton-strikeouts-innings-dodgers-offense-rockies", "title": "James Paxton's best game of the year comes at Coors Field", "body": "James Paxton pitched his best game of the year, and it came at Coors Field of all places. That allowed the Dodgers to cruise while exhibiting some offensive patience in a 9-5 win over the Rockies in Monday night's series opener in Denver.\n\nJust about everything was working for Paxton, who struck out a season-best eight batters in a season-hight seven innings, retiring 21 of his 25 batters faced. The lone run against him was a solo homer by Jacob Stallings in the second inning, an aptly named batter since his home run interrupted Kirsten Watson explaining the Dodgers city connect uniforms on the SportsNet LA broadcast.\n\nPaxton found success by pounding the strike zone, completing his seven innings in just 91 pitches, and continued a trend over the last month and a half.\n\nThe left-hander led the world with 22 walks during an April, with a 19.3-percent walk rate that was so far out of line with Paxton's career norms. But since then, after some mechanical fixes, he has been able to limit the free passes, with just a 6.67-percent walk rate in his last eight starts.\n\nThat stinginess allowed Paxton to complete at least six innings five times in his last eight starts.\n\nPaxton's only walk on Monday came with two outs in the seventh inning, and Paxton got three strikeouts in that frame to keep the walk from hurting him. He induced 15 swinging strikes against the Rockies, also a season high.\n\nNobody against Paxton, outside of maybe Stallings in the batters box with the bases empty, batted with a runner in scoring position on Monday.\n\nOn the other side, Rockies starter Cal Quantrill really had to work to get through his night. The Dodgers had runners on in every inning against him, and got him out of the game after five innings and 99 pitches. Eleven batters reached base against Quantrill alone, but the Dodgers had to scratch and claw to plate the three runs they did score with him in the game.\n\nAll three runs against Quantrill came in the first two innings, all scored on two-out, two-strike hits. Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez opened the scoring by winning a 10-pitch battle with an RBI double in the first inning to score Freddie Freeman.\n\nIn the second inning, Shohei Ohtani singled home Miguel Rojas, then No. 2 hitter Will Smith tripled home Ohtani.\n\nThe fruits of that early labor paid off for the Dodgers against the Rockies bullpen, as they threatened in the final four innings as well. Rojas doubled home a run in the seventh, his third hit of the night in his first game since assuming the role of regular shortstop. Cavan Biggio singled home Rojas for his frist RBI in five games with the Dodgers.\n\nJason Heyward also had three hits, including a two-run single in the eighth that provided more insurance.\n\nTwo more runs came in the ninth, including a double by Gavin Lux, the Dodgers' sixth extra-base hit of the night.\n\nFreeman had an interesting night, tying a Dodgers record with five walks, the last of which was intentional. He broke that streak with a ninth-inning single. {"uri": "8184695437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:27:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:27:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:26:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/ap/sports/haywards-slam-hernandezs-3-run-shot-highlight-7-run-ninth-as-dodgers-beat-rockies-11/article_20f9e47a-20f7-5eda-91a1-4dc9a8354970.html", "title": "Hayward's slam, Hernandez's 3-run shot highlight 7-run ninth as Dodgers beat Rockies 11-9", "body": "DENVER (AP) -- Jason Heyward hit a pinch-hit grand slam and Teoscar Hernandez added a three-run homer -- all in a seven-run ninth inning -- as the Los Angeles Dodgers rallied for a wild 11-9 victory over the Colorado Rockies on Tuesday night.\n\n\"It was quality of at-bat up and down the lineup,\" Los Angeles manager Dave Roberts said. \"Jason was ready when called upon. Teo, he keeps coming up with big hits. That inning, certainly, the results showed the fight, the compete.\"\n\nHeyward's fourth career grand slam came off Tyler Kinley and followed walks by Andy Pages and Miguel Vargas around a single by Miguel Rojas. Heyward's fourth homer of the season hit the right field foul pole and pulled the Dodgers within 9-8 with one out in the inning after they trailed 7-2 after four.\n\n\"I wasn't sure if it was going to stay fair or not,\" said Heyward, who hit an inside slider, \"It's Colorado, so maybe that helped it straighten out a little bit. I was like, 'Come on, squeak in, squeak in.' I honestly feel like we got rewarded for our process\" in the ninth.\n\nShohei Ohtani, who had a 476-foot homer in the fifth, singled off Victor Vodnik (1-1) before Will Smith struck out looking after attempting to step out of the batter's box on a 3-2 pitch.\n\nAfter a wild pitch, Freddie Freeman received an intentional walk, his sixth walk in the last two games, bringing up Hernandez. Hernandez took a half-swing at a 1-2 fastball and first base umpire Lance Barksdale ruled that Hernandez did not commit. Colorado manager Bud Black argued the call and was ejected.\n\nOn the next pitch, Hernandez hit his 18th home to make it 11-9.\n\nAfter Hernandez's ball cleared the wall, Colorado right field Jake Cave immediately took a few steps toward Barksdale and began yelling. Rockies' second baseman Alan Trejo stepped between Cave and Barksdale after the inning ended.\n\n\"It was close,\" Hernandez said. \"You can call it either way and it will be fine. When Jason hit the grand slam and turning the lineup over to Ohtani, you know something was going to happen. I just wanted to get a good pitch hit to tie the game. I put a little extra and it went over the fence. I knew as soon as I hit. It was great, especially because it put the team ahead.\"\n\nEvan Phillips got the only batter he faced, Hunter Goodman, with a runner on second to record his 11th save in as many chances. Cave, the on-deck hitter, was restrained by bench Mike Redmond as he attempted to reach Barksdale after the game ended.\n\n\"When I'm running in (before the last of the ninth), he looks me right in the face and goes, 'Cave, it's not even close,'\" Cave said. \"Everybody in the world could see it was at least close. And he did swing. It's a big game, it's one of the best teams in baseball and we're battling with them.\n\n\"That game's won on that swing, That's a swing-and-miss, the game's won, and we beat the Los Angeles Dodgers.\"\n\nElehuris Montero and Brenton Doyle homered for the Rockies, who scored four runs in the first and twice led by five runs.\n\nDoyle added three singles for his first career four-hit game, scored twice, and made a diving catch of Ohtani's line drive to right-center field with runners on first and second and two outs in the seventh inning, preserving an 8-4 lead.\n\nDodgers starter Walker Buehler gave up eight hits and seven runs in four innings. It was the first time the 29-yeaer-old right-hander allowed more than three earned runs since returning to the rotation May 6 after missing the 2023 season because of Tommy John surgery. He struck out two and walked one.\n\nPages also homered for the Dodgers, who have won four of five and are 73-32 against Colorado since 2018. The Rockies have lost five of six.\n\nMichael Petersen (1-0) worked two innings of relief and struck out two in his major league debut.\n\n\"It was crazy,\" said Petersen, whose relatives were in attendance. \"You can't feel anything. It's like your first date, you are tripping over stuff. But awesome.\"\n\nTRAINER'S ROOM\n\nDodgers: LHP Clayton Kershaw (shoulder surgery) is scheduled to pitch three innings for Class A Rancho Cucamonga on Wednesday in his first rehab start of the season. \"He's doing fantastic,\" manager Dave Roberts said, adding that Kershaw will follow the natural progression of two or three more rehab starts \"and then we'll see where we are at.\"\n\nRockies: DH/OF Charlie Blackmon (right hamstring tightness) was removed after suffering his injury while running the bases in the first. ... LHP Kyle Freeland (elbow strain) gave up two hits and two runs and struck out four in four innings of a rehab start for Triple-A Albuquerque on Tuesday and appears close to returning. ... 2B Brendan Rodgers (hamstring) did normal pregame work Tuesday and is expected to begin a rehab assignment on Thursday with an eye toward a weekend activation. ... OF Sean Bouchard (ankle) led off and was 1 for 3 with two walks as the DH for Albuquerque.\n\nNEXT UP\n\nDodgers RHP Bobby Miller (1-1, 5.40 ERA) will oppose Rockies RHP Ryan Feltner (1-6, 5.71) in the third game of a four-game series. Miller will make his fourth start, his first since April 10, after missing nine weeks with right shoulder inflammation. Heyward's fourth homer of the season pulled the Dodgers within 9-8 with one out in the inning after trailing 7-2 after four innings.\n\nShohei Ohtani, who had a 476-foot homer in the fifth, singled off Victor Vodnik (1-1) before Will Smith struck out looking after attempting to step out of the batter's box on a 3-2 pitch.\n\nAfter a wild pitch, Freddie Freeman received an intentional walk, his sixth walk in the last two games, bringing up Hernandez. Hernandez took a half-swing at a 1-2 fastball, but first base umpire Lance Barksdale ruled that Hernandez did not commit. Colorado manager Bud Black argued the call and was ejected.\n\nOn the next pitch, Hernandez hit his 18th home to make it 11-9. After Hernandez's ball cleared the wall, Colorado right field Jake Cave immediately took a few steps toward Barksdale and began yelling. Rockies' second baseman Alan Trejo stepped between Cave and Barksdale after the inning ended.\n\nEvan Phillips got the only batter he faced, Hunter Goodman, to recorded his 11th save in as many chances. Cave, the on-deck hitter, was restrained by bench Mike Redmond as he attempted to reach Bardsdale.\n\nElehuris Montero and Brenton Doyle homered for the Rockies, who scored four runs in the first and twice led by five runs.\n\nDoyle added three singles for his first career four-hit game, scored twice, and made a diving catch of Ohtani's line drive to right-center field with runners on first and second and two outs in the seventh inning, preserving an 8-4 lead.\n\nDodgers starter Walker Buehler gave up eight hits and seven runs in four innings. It was the first time the 29-yeaer-old right-hander allowed more than three earned runs since returning to the rotation May 6 after missing the 2023 season because of Tommy John surgery. He struck out two and walked one.\n\nMichael Petersen (1-0) worked two innings of relief and struck out two for the win.\n\nTRAINER'S ROOM\n\nDodgers: LHP Clayton Kershaw (shoulder surgery) is scheduled to pitch three innings for Class A Rancho Cucamonga on Wednesday in his first rehab start of the season. \"He's doing fantastic,\" manager Dave Roberts said, adding that Kershaw will follow the natural progression of two or three more rehab starts \"and then we'll see where we are at.\"\n\nRockies: DH/OF Charlie Blackmon (right hamstring tightness) was removed after suffering his injury while running the bases in the first. ... LHP Kyle Freeland (elbow strain) gave up two hits and two runs and struck out four in four innings of a rehab start for Triple-A Albuquerque on Tuesday and appears close to returning. ... 2B Brendan Rodgers (hamstring) did normal pregame work Tuesday and is expected to begin a rehab assignment on Thursday with an eye toward a weekend activation. ... OF Sean Bouchard (ankle) led off and was 1 for 3 with two walks as the DH for Albuquerque.\n\nNEXT UP\n\nDodgers RHP Bobby Miller (1-1, 5.40 ERA) will oppose Rockies RHP Ryan Feltner (1-6, 5.71) in the third game of a four-game series. Miller will make his fourth start, his first since April 10, after missing nine weeks with right shoulder inflammation. He won in his only previous appearance at Coors Field, 7-2, on Sept. 26, 2023.\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/hub/mlb", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Teo, he keeps coming up with big hits. That inning, certainly, the results showed the fight, the compete.\"\n\nAccording to Elias Sports Bureau research, the Dodgers had lost 1,137 straight games when trailing by five or more runs in the ninth inning or later, dating back to 1957, their last year in Brooklyn. It was the second-longest active losing streak in that scenario. Only the Mariners (1,234 losses and 0 wins in franchise history) had a longer such losing streak.\n\nWith their comeback win Tuesday, the Dodgers are now 6-2,619 all-time when trailing by five or more runs in the ninth inning or later. Their seven runs were also their most scored in a ninth inning since 2004 against the San Francisco Giants (also seven).\n\nHeyward's fourth career grand slam came off Tyler Kinley and followed walks by Andy Pages and Miguel Vargas around a single by Miguel Rojas. Heyward's fourth homer of the season hit the right field foul pole and pulled the Dodgers within 9-8 with one out in the inning after they trailed 7-2 after four.\n\n\"I wasn't sure if it was going to stay fair or not,\" said Heyward, who hit an inside slider, \"It's Colorado, so maybe that helped it straighten out a little bit. I was like, 'Come on, squeak in, squeak in.' I honestly feel like we got rewarded for our process\" in the ninth.\n\nShohei Ohtani, who had a 476-foot homer in the fifth, singled off Victor Vodnik (1-1) before Will Smith struck out looking after attempting to step out of the batter's box on a 3-2 pitch.\n\nAfter a wild pitch, Freddie Freeman received an intentional walk, his sixth walk in the last two games, bringing up Hernandez. Hernandez took a half-swing at a 1-2 fastball and first base umpire Lance Barksdale ruled that Hernandez did not commit. Colorado manager Bud Black argued the call and was ejected.\n\nOn the next pitch, Hernandez hit his 18th home run to make it 11-9. It was the first time the Dodgers had hit a grand slam and a three-run homer in the ninth inning in their 140-year history.\n\nAfter Hernandez's ball cleared the wall, Colorado right fielder Jake Cave immediately took a few steps toward Barksdale and began yelling. Rockies second baseman Alan Trejo stepped between Cave and Barksdale after the inning ended.\n\n\"It was close,\" Hernandez said. \"You can call it either way and it will be fine. When Jason hit the grand slam and turning the lineup over to Ohtani, you know something was going to happen. I just wanted to get a good pitch hit to tie the game. I put a little extra and it went over the fence. I knew as soon as I hit. It was great, especially because it put the team ahead.\"\n\nEvan Phillips got the only batter he faced, Hunter Goodman, with a runner on second to record his 11th save in as many chances. Cave, the on-deck hitter, was restrained by bench Mike Redmond as he attempted to reach Barksdale after the game ended.\n\n\"When I'm running in (before the last of the ninth), he looks me right in the face and goes, 'Cave, it's not even close,'\" Cave said. \"Everybody in the world could see it was at least close. And he did swing. It's a big game, it's one of the best teams in baseball and we're battling with them.\n\n\"That game's won on that swing, That's a swing-and-miss, the game's won, and we beat the Los Angeles Dodgers.\"\n\nElehuris Montero and Brenton Doyle homered for the Rockies, who scored four runs in the first and twice led by five runs.\n\nDoyle added three singles for his first career four-hit game, scored twice, and made a diving catch of Ohtani's line drive to right-center field with runners on first and second and two outs in the seventh inning, preserving an 8-4 lead.\n\nDodgers starter Walker Buehler gave up eight hits and seven runs in four innings. It was the first time the 29-yeaer-old right-hander allowed more than three earned runs since returning to the rotation May 6 after missing the 2023 season because of Tommy John surgery. He struck out two and walked one.\n\nPages also homered for the Dodgers, who have won four of five and are 73-32 against Colorado since 2018. The Rockies have lost five of six.\n\nMichael Petersen (1-0) worked two innings of relief and struck out two in his major league debut.\n\n\"It was crazy,\" said Petersen, whose relatives were in attendance. \"You can't feel anything. {"uri": "2024-06-393061339", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "06:37:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T06:37:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T05:49:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.southernminn.com/around_the_web/sports/freddie-freeman-walks-5-times-as-dodgers-down-rockies/article_7eb72874-9b3e-577e-b4c2-57e201d3abd2.html", "title": "Freddie Freeman walks 5 times as Dodgers down Rockies", "body": "Shohei Ohtani had three hits and scored twice, Freddie Freeman walked five times, and the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Colorado Rockies 9-5 in Denver on Monday. Freeman walked in his first four plate appearances before drawing an intentional pass in the eighth inning, tying a franchise record for walks in one game. Max Muncy was the last Dodger player to do it, drawing five walks on April 25, 2021. Freeman added a ninth-inning single. Jason Heyward and Miguel Rojas also had three hits and James Paxton tossed seven strong innings for Los Angeles. Paxton (7-1) allowed one run on two hits and a walk while striking out a season-high eight in his longest outing of the season. Greg Jones homered with two outs in the ninth for his first career hit and Jacob Stallings and Hunter Goodman also went deep for the Rockies. The Dodgers scored in the first inning when Freeman drew a two-out walk and came home on Teoscar Hernandez's double to right. Los Angeles added on in the second. Rojas led off with a single and eventually scored on Ohtani's two-out base hit, and Will Smith tripled to the right field corner to give Los Angeles a 3-0 lead. Ohtani batted leadoff in the Dodgers' first game after Mookie Betts sustained a fractured left hand on Sunday. Betts is expected to return at some point this season. Stallings led off the bottom of the second with his fourth home run of the season to put Colorado on the board. Rockies starter Cal Quantrill (6-5) settled down after the second to pitch five innings. He allowed three runs on seven hits with three walks and three strikeouts to keep his team in the game, but the Dodgers extended their lead against reliever Geoff Hartlieb in the seventh. Heyward singled and scored on a double by Rojas, and Cavan Biggio drove in Rojas with a single up the middle to make it 5-1. Hartlieb avoided more damage when Gavin Lux grounded into a double play to end the inning. Heyward knocked in a pair of runs with a bases-loaded single in the eighth. Biggio scored on Lux's double in the ninth before Lux came in on Smith's sacrifice fly to round out the Dodgers' scoring. Colorado scored four times with two outs in the ninth, capped by Goodman's two-run blast, his fifth of the season. --Field Level Media\n\nFeatured Local Savings", "source": {"uri": "southernminn.com", Anyone who left the game early with the Rockies taking a five-run lead into the ninth inning probably spent some time sitting in their cars swearing. Dodgers fans would have been upset they missed an incredible comeback while Rockies fans would have just been upset.\n\nThe Dodgers began their comeback with a Jason Heyward grand slam to make it a one-run game with one out. Following a pitching change Shohei Ohtani singled, Will Smith struck out for the second out of the inning and Freddie Freeman was intentionally walked so Victor Vodnik could face Teoscar Hernandez.\n\nOn a 1-2 pitch Vodnik threw Hernandez a high fastball that he really wanted to swing at. In fact, he started to swing before stopping himself. First base umpire Lance Barksdale ruled that he did not go around, saving Hernandez from striking out. The Rockies really hated the call and their worst fears were immediately confirmed. Instead of the game being over Hernandez got one more pitch and hit a go-ahead three-run home run.\n\nIf you'd like to see an emotional avatar of Rockies fans after that home run, look no further than right fielder Jake Cave who was visibly furious. He discussed his freakout in the locker room after the game.\n\n\"That game's won on that swing,\" Cave said. \"That's a swing and a miss and the game's won and we beat the Los Angeles Dodgers. So yeah I'm pissed. I kind of lost my mind on him a little bit. Got a little more mad when he looked at me and told me it wasn't even close because then you're not even taking any accountability for you know, basically, you know screwing us over. So yeah I was pretty pissed. Still pretty pissed. I think everybody is.\"\n\nIt's an almost unbelievable way to lose, but when you combine the Dodgers lineup and that Colorado air it starts to make sense. Throw in some help from the umpires and the unbelievable seems inevitable.\n\nOr maybe there's a higher power stepping in after the Dodgers lost Mookie Betts for a prolonged period of time. The Rockies added onto their lead with a run in the fourth inning, and the teams traded scores in the sixth and seventh.\n\nUp to that point the Dodgers had received home runs from Andy Pages and Shohei Ohtani, and Miguel Vargas contributed with an RBI double.\n\nThe improbable comeback in the ninth inning began with Pages' leadoff walk that was followed by a base hit from Miguel Rojas. Vargas' walk loaded the bases for pinch-hitter Jason Heyward, who delivered a grand slam to get the Dodgers back within a run.\n\nOhtani singled but the Dodgers then found themselves down to their last out when Will Smith struck out looking. {"uri": "8186339273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "04:56:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T04:56:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T04:55:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/rockies-rebound-from-tough-loss-to-edge-dodgers-in-ninth-inning-5671846", "title": "Rockies Rebound From Tough Loss to Edge Dodgers in Ninth Inning", "body": "DENVER -- Brenton Doyle broke a ninth-inning tie with a sacrifice fly, enabling the Colorado Rockies to rebound from a tough loss the night before and beat the Los Angeles Dodgers 7-6 on Wednesday.\n\nDoyle's fly ball to center field scored Jake Cave from third base, giving Colorado the victory some 24 hours after the Rockies blew a five-run, ninth-inning lead in an 11-9 loss.\n\n\"I was trying to get a ball up in the zone to allow me to drive the ball somewhere in the air and deep enough to score Jake,\" Doyle said.\n\nCave and Elhehuris Montero led off the ninth with singles off Yohan Ramirez (0-3), and rookie Adael Amador, who had two hits, reached on a fielder's choice.\n\nTuesday night's loss came when the Dodgers' Teoscar Hernandez hit a go-ahead, three-run home run with two outs after first-base umpire Lance Barksdale ruled the slugger had checked his swing on what would have been a game-ending strike three.\n\nCave, who was animated as he yelled at Barksdale from right field, disputing that call, said Wednesday's win had more meaning.\n\n\"Baseball is kind of poetic, and this is a little glimpse of that,\" Cave said. \"With some drama happening late [Tuesday] night, to be in the ninth inning, tie ballgame, couple of runners on and no outs, I get the chance to score the winning run.\"\n\nMichael Toglia homered and tripled, and Jalen Beeks (3-3) pitched an inning of relief to help Colorado snap a four-game losing streak.\n\nShohei Ohtani doubled, singled, and drove in three runs for Los Angeles. Freddie Freeman also had two hits for the Dodgers.\n\nLos Angeles' Bobby Miller made his first start since April 10 after spending more than two months on the injured list because of inflammation in his right shoulder.\n\nAfter Toglia hit a three-run homer off Miller in the first inning, the Dodgers took a 4-3 lead in the second on Ohtani's three-run double and Freeman's RBI single.\n\n\"The adrenaline was pretty high in the first inning. Got a couple of quick outs and then a two-out walk,\" Miller said. \"[Toglia], I missed a fastball down the middle. I'd like to think if I throw it in a different spot, I'd only let up two runs.\"\n\nJason Heyward, who hit a grand slam to start Los Angeles' seven-run ninth inning Tuesday night, doubled home two runs in the fifth off Rockies starter Ryan Feltner.\n\nMiller went 6 1/3 innings-his longest outing this year-but was denied the victory when Colorado scored twice in the seventh.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8187766605", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "22:10:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T22:10:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T22:09:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://apnews.com/article/dodgers-rockies-score-b75d8dbf73ca10075b6153308a593d57", "title": "Ohtani hits 21st homer, Smith and Freeman go deep in the Dodgers' 5-3 victory over the Rockies", "body": "DENVER (AP) -- Shohei Ohtani led off the game with his 21st homer of the season, Will Smith and Freddie Freeman hit back-to-back homers in the fourth inning, and the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Colorado Rockies 5-3 on Thursday.\n\nOhtani's homer was his fourth in five games, and Smith and Freeman each hit their 11th for a 5-0 lead off Ty Blach (3-5) to help the Dodgers take three of four from the Rockies.\n\nOhtani is 8 for 18 with two homers, three doubles and six RBIs in four games as the leadoff hitter, moving up a spot in the order after Mookie Betts broke his left hand when he was hit by a pitch Sunday.\n\nJake Cave had a two-run single when Colorado closed within 5-2 in the sixth inning, and Ryan McMahon hit a 462-foot homer off Alex Vesia to lead off the eighth.\n\nEvan Phillips pitched a 1-2-3 ninth for his 12th save in as many chances. The Rockies have lost four of five.\n\nGavin Stone (8-2) gave up two runs and four hits, all singles, in 5 1/3 innings. He tied a season high with seven strikeouts, all swinging, walked two and hit a batter.\n\nStone recorded three strikeouts with his mid-90s fastball and two apiece with a curveball and a changeup. He is 7-1 with a 2.18 ERA in 10 starts since April 26.\n\nTeoscar Hern\u00e1ndez had three hits and scored a run, Freeman had two hits and Chris Taylor had two hits and two stolen bases. Freeman pulled up after reaching on an infield single in the ninth but remained in the game after a visit from manager David Roberts and a member of the training staff.\n\nMcMahon and Cave each had two of the Rockies' six hits.\n\nOhtani's homer to center field just got over the fence and the outstretched glove of Brenton Doyle, who collided with the fence at the 415-foot sign.\n\nOhtani will face the Los Angeles Angels in a two-game series at Dodger Stadium beginning Friday, a first since he signed a 10-year, $700 million free-agent deal with the crosstown Dodgers after six seasons with the Angels.\n\n\"I think he is grateful for his time in Anaheim, grateful for the fans,\" manager Dave Roberts said. \"I think he wants to get it over with and help the Dodgers win.\"\n\nDodgers: LHP Clayton Kershaw (offseason shoulder surgery) struck out five in three innings of his first rehab appearance Wednesday for Class A Rancho Cucamonga. He is expected to throw four innings in his next rehab game.\n\nRockies: LHP Kyle Freeland (elbow) is to start Sunday in his return from the injured list, his first appearance since April 14. ... RF/DH Charlie Blackmon (hamstring) missed his second straight game and his progress in the next 48 hours will inform the decision of whether to place him on the IL, manager Bud Black said. ... 2B Brendan Rodgers (hamstring) was to begin at rehab assignment for Triple-A Albuquerque on Thursday and could be reactivated Sunday. ... RHP German Marquez (Tommy John surgery) is set to start for Class A Spokane on Saturday. ... SS Ezequiel Tovar did not start of the second time this season but entered as a defensive replacement in the eighth.\n\nDodgers: Roberts said he will use a bullpen game or a spot starter in the series opener against the Angels, who will go with left-hander Patrick Sandoval (2-8, 5.24 ERA).\n\nRockies: RHP Dakota Hudson (2-9, 4.86 ERA) is set to oppose Washington LHP DJ Herz (1-1, 3.77) in the Freddie Freeman also had two hits for the Dodgers.\n\nLos Angeles' Bobby Miller made his first start since April 10 after spending more than two months on the injured list because of inflammation in his right shoulder.\n\nAfter Toglia hit a three-run homer off Miller in the first inning, the Dodgers took a 4-3 lead in the second on Ohtani's three-run double and Freeman's RBI single.\n\n\"The adrenaline was pretty high in the first inning, got a couple of quick outs and then a two-out walk,\" Miller said. \"(Toglia), I missed a fastball down the middle. {"uri": "8182845445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "03:41:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T03:41:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T03:40:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.denverpost.com/2024/06/17/dodgers-dominate-rockies-series-opener/", "title": "Dodgers dominate Rockies in series opener, improve to 40 games over .500 against Colorado since Game 163 in 2018", "body": "The Rockies' closest shot at the NL West title feels like a long-off dream.\n\nIn the series opener on Monday at Coors Field, the Dodgers made the Rockies look like little brother again in a 9-5 win. Dating back to when L.A. beat Colorado in 2018's Game 163 to win the divisional title, Monday's victory improved the Dodgers to 40 games over .500 (72-32) against the outmatched Rockies.\n\nL.A. struck first in the opening inning, using Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez's RBI double to score Freddie Freeman. That run was a bad omen for the Rockies, considering the Dodgers entered the evening with an MLB-best 89.2 winning percentage when scoring first.\n\nThe Dodgers improved to 34-4 on the season in that regard despite Cal Quantrill, the Rockies' best pitcher this year, keeping the home team in it for the first half of the game.\n\nWhile Quantrill threw five innings of three-run ball against one of baseball's top offenses, the Colorado bats fell flat until the very end.\n\nThe Rockies only mustered two hits through the first eight innings: Jacob Stallings' solo homer off James Paxton in the second, and Nolan Jones' single off Paxton in the sixth.\n\nAfter taking an early 1-0 lead, L.A. tacked on two runs in the second. Shohei Ohtani roped an RBI single to right and Will Smith followed with an RBI triple, also to right that hit off the foul line.\n\nL.A. then broke the game open against Geoff Hartlieb in the seventh and eighth to make it 7-1. The Dodgers plated two runs off the right-hander in the seventh and two more in the eighth in a frame sparked by Ohtani's leadoff walk and then steal of second.\n\nJustin Lawrence gave up two runs in the ninth via Gavin Lux's RBI double and Smith's sacrifice fly to pad the Dodgers' lead. The side-armer, reinstated from the IL before the game, threw 42 pitches across the eighth and ninth.\n\nOhtani finished 3 for 5 with a walk, an RBI and two runs scored. Each knock by the Japanese sensation was met with a roar from the blue-clad crowd, and when his steal upheld a Colorado challenge, the L.A. fans on hand went crazy.\n\nAs Ohtani lived up to the hype, fellow Dodgers slugger Freddie Freeman walked his way into history. The first baseman drew five walks, one of them intentional, for just the second five-walk game ever at Coors Field. Freeman joined Cooperstown-bound Todd Helton, who walked five times against the Braves on April 29, 2007. Like Helton, Freeman also had a single.\n\nIn garbage time with two outs in the ninth, the Rockies staged a rally that was way too little, too late. Greg Jones roped his first career hit and homer to right field off JP Feyereisen. Michael Toglia and Elehuris Montero followed with consecutive doubles, then Hunter Goodman's two-run blast made it 9-5 before Alan Trejo K'd to end the game.\n\nRoster moves. Ahead of Monday's series opener, Colorado made a handful of roster moves. The Rockies reinstated right-handers Jake Bird and Justin Lawrence from the 15-day injured list, bolstering the bullpen, while placing southpaw reliever Josh Rogers on the 15-day IL with a left rotator cuff strain.\n\nManager Bud Black said Rogers underwent an MRI on Monday to determine the severity of the injury. In a corresponding move, right-hander Angel Chivilli was optioned back to Double-A Hartford.\n\nBlack hopes the return of Bird and Lawrence will help even out Colorado's \"uneven\" bullpen, which carried an MLB-worst 5.70 ERA into Monday's game.\n\nInjury updates. Second baseman Brendan Rodgers, who strained his hamstring running out of the box on June 8 in St. Louis, is nearing a return. He's been doing full baseball activities the last few days, including baserunning and hitting on Monday. He hopes to be back for the Nationals series this weekend, but it could be longer.\n\n\"It was pretty minor and when I initially did it, I knew it was going to be in the range of 10-15 days, and I'm right in that time frame and feeling a lot better,\" Rodgers said.\n\nWhen Rodgers gets back to the lineup, rookie Adael Amador, the club's top prospect, will likely be sent back to Double-A Hartford.\n\nRight-hander German Marquez continues his trajectory back to the big-league lineup from Tommy John surgery. He threw two-plus innings on Sunday with Low-A Fresno, allowing four runs on six hits. Black said \"he pitched better than the line indicated, the most important thing is after after the game he felt wonderful, and had no problems with the arm.\"\n\nMarquez now heads to High-A Spokane for another rehab start later this week. The goal remains to have him back in LoDo around the all-star break.\n\nOutfielder Sean Bouchard (ankle sprain) and left-hander Kyle Freeland (elbow strain) are both playing for Triple-A Albuquerque on Tuesday in Oklahoma City.", "source": {"uri": "denverpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Denver Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kyle_newman@denverpost.com", "name": "Kyle Newman", "type": He and Elehuris Montero singled to set the table for Adael Amador, who grounded into a force out at second\n\nThe game-winning run, which Cave scored directly in front of home plate umpire Lance Barksdale, tasted especially sweet. Cave was the Rockies' most furious player after Barksdale's missed call from first base on a check swing cost Colorado the final out of Tuesday's game.\n\nThe Rockies are 5-14 against the Dodgers since the start of the 2023 season. They will attempt to earn a four-game split Thursday in a matinee at Coors Field.\n\nThey earned another head start against their seemingly insurmountable division rival when Michael Toglia took Bobby Miller deep for a 3-0 first-inning lead. Toglia was on cycle watch after tripling his next at-bat, but that fizzled out by the end of a 2-for-4 night.\n\nThe Dodgers didn't need all nine innings to conjure a comeback this time. They only needed one opportunity. Shohei Ohtani, attracting an enthusiastic reception before every plate appearance, cleared the bases with a two-out double into the left-center alley. He scored on a Freddie Freeman single, and it was 4-3 Los Angeles by the bottom of the second.\n\nMiller shook off the early home run and settled in for the Dodgers in his first appearance since April 10, carrying a 6-4 lead into the seventh after Jason Heyward's go-ahead two-run double. But Dave Roberts might have left his starter on the mound a little too long. Miller gave up a leadoff double to Sean Bouchard then got the first out before exiting to a small ovation from Dodgers fans.\n\nDaniel Hudson's first pitch was grounded to third by Montero and bobbled by Cavan Biggio, a run-scoring error that breathed new life into Coors Field. The tying runner was on, and eventually around the bases after an Amador double and the first of Doyle's clutch productive outs. The final line for Miller included five earned runs.\n\nRockies pitcher Ryan Feltner gave up all of the Dodgers' six runs in a five-inning start, striking out six and walking two.\n\nCharlie Blackmon did not play in Wednesday's game due to right hamstring tightness, an injury Rockies manager Bud Black described as day-to-day moving forward. Black didn't rule out a Blackmon appearance when he spoke to reporters pregame, but he said the veteran designated hitter would \"probably not\" be available.\n\nBlackmon was removed from the game Tuesday after injuring his hamstring while running the bases. He was hit by a pitch in the first inning and advanced gingerly to third base after pulling up as he rounded second.\n\nRockies left fielder Nolan Jones was also scratched from the lineup before the first pitch due to illness. He is 3-2 with a 3.76 ERA in eight outings at Coors Field in 2024. His numbers have also been impressive against the Dodgers: a 3.13 career ERA in 77.2 innings pitched. Blach has faced exactly 25 batters in each of his last three starts, allowing seven or more hits including a home run and not making it through the sixth inning. He has a 5.74 ERA during that stretch, but he struck out 10 and walked only two across those starts. This will be Blach's first time facing the Dodgers this season.\n\nStone is fresh off a seven-inning no-decision on June 14 against the Royals. He pitched against the Rockies on June 2, tossing five scoreless while striking out six in a win for Los Angeles. The 25-year-old has a 5.11 career ERA on the road in 44 innings. {"uri": "8184594405", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:44:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:44:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:43:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/dodgers-stars-jayson-heyward-teoscar-hernandez-power-wild-ninth-inning-rally-to-stun-rockies-034249240.html", "title": "Dodgers stars Jayson Heyward, Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez power wild ninth inning rally to stun Rockies", "body": "Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez's three-run home run in the ninth inning came with two outs and two strikes, too\n\nBy all accounts, the Dodgers should have lost on Tuesday night in Denver.\n\nAfter falling into a five-run deficit almost immediately at Coors Field, the Dodgers entered the ninth inning down 9-4. The game was three outs away from being over.\n\nOf course, that's when they finally came alive.\n\nThe Dodgers, behind two massive home runs from Jayson Heyward and Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez, pulled off an improbable rally to claim an 11-9 win over the Colorado Rockies. They put up seven runs in the ninth inning alone.\n\nFirst, after loading up the bases, it was Heyward who drilled a grand slam with his deep shot off the right field foul pole. That suddenly made it a one-run game.\n\nThen, with two outs and two strikes on him, Hern\u00e1ndez followed suit. He hit a three-run home run himself to put the Dodgers in the lead for the first time all night.\n\nFrom there, the Dodgers quickly shut down the Rockies in the bottom of the inning to grab the win.\n\nThe Dodgers entered the ninth inning with four runs on the board, thanks largely to star Shohei Ohtani. He had two hits, two RBI and a massive solo home run in the sixth inning -- which traveled a season-record 476 feet into center field off of Rockies pitcher Austin Gomber.\n\nOhtani now has 20 home runs and 91 hits and 49 RBI on the year.\n\nThe win marked the Dodgers' fourth in their last five games and second straight over the Rockies. They hold a 46-29 record, which is good for a massive lead in the NL West, heading into Wednesday's game in Denver -- which will be the third in the four-game series against the Rockies.\n\nThe {"uri": "8184628004", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:18:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:18:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:17:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.truebluela.com/2024/6/18/24181056/jason-heyward-teoscar-hernandez-home-runs-ninth-inning-comeback-dodgers-rockies", "title": "Dodgers make most of borrowed time at Coors Field", "body": "Down five runs in the ninth inning, the Dodgers staged their wildest comeback to date this season, stunning the Rockies with an 11-9 win on Tuesday night at Coors Field.\n\nFacing Tyler Kinley in the ninth, Andy Pages walked and Miguel Rojas singled to open the frame, then one out later Miguel Vargas walked to load the bases. Jason Heyward pinch-hit for Chris Taylor, and promptly hit a grand slam to get the Dodgers closer than they'd been since the top of the first inning.\n\nThen things got very weird.\n\nShohei Ohtani singled off Victor Vodnik, putting the tying run on base. Will Smith on a 3-2 pitch tried to verbally call time then inexplicably stepped out of the box as a third strike crossed the plate. Home plate umpire Will Little did not grant time, making Smith the second out.\n\nThen came Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez, who fell behind 1-2, then tried to check his swing on an outside pitch. First base umpire Lance Barksdale agreed that Hern\u00e1ndez did in fact check his swing, which angered just about everyone on the Rockies, from Jake Cave in right field to Vodnik on the mound. Manager Bud Black got ejected and might have set a record for most times saying \"That's fucking bullshit\" in one sitting.\n\nHad that been ruled a swing, the game would be over, a tough Dodgers loss. But granted new life, Hern\u00e1ndez mauled the next pitch he saw for a game-winning three-run shot to right field.\n\nThis was shades of August 31, 2016, when the Dodgers trailed by five in the eighth inning at Coors Field. They scored three in the eighth and five in the ninth, the latter punctuated by an Andrew Toles grand slam.\n\nBut Tuesday night was even wilder.\n\nThat the Dodgers were even in this position was unbelievable, as they trailed by four runs after one inning and five runs after two. Walker Buehler had his worst start since returning from the injured list. More on that later.\n\nThe Dodgers chipped away at the deficit, but after batting in the top of the first inning they never pulled closer than to within three runs until the ninth. The Rockies answered three of the Dodgers' four one-run innings by scoring immediately in the bottom of the frame, and in the other instance Colorado waited only one inning to get back that run.\n\nPages and Ohtani each hit home runs. Ohtani's homer was his fifth in the last eight games and 20th of the season.\n\nAt 476 feet, it's the longest MLB home run of the season, and the second-longest homer hit by a Dodger dating back to 2015, when Statcast started tracking such things. The only longer Dodgers home run during that time was by then-rookie Joc Pederson, who hit a 477-foot homer on June 2, 2015, also at Coors Field.\n\nDown four with two outs and two runners on in the seventh, Ohtani hit the snot out of the ball again, but his 111.7-mph, would-be two-run extra-base hit instead died in the glove a diving Doyle in center field, one of the best catches you'll see this season.\n\nMichael Petersen made his major league debut in the seventh inning, two days after he was called up from Triple-A by the Dodgers. The 30-year-old right-hander walked his first batter, Nolan Jones, who advanced to third on a single and scored on a sacrifice fly. Petersen settled down in a perfect eighth inning, striking out both Montero and Doyle, each of whom homered earlier, for his first two major league strikeouts.\n\nPetersen is the first Dodger born in the United Kingdom. He's the 28th different pitcher used by the Dodgers this season, tied with the Brewers for second-most in the majors this season, one behind the Marlins.\n\nThanks to the improbable comeback, Petersen for his efforts not only made his debut, but picked up his first major league win. He's just the 14th Dodgers pitcher since 1901 to earn the win in relief in his MLB debut, and the first since Dennis Santana in 2018, also at Coors Field.\n\nHome runs: Andy Pages (8), Shohei Ohtani (20), Jason Heyward (4), Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez (18); Elehuris Montero (4), Brenton Doyle (6)\n\nBobby Miller will be activated from the injured list to make his first start for the Dodgers in 10 weeks on Wednesday (5:40 p.m. PT, SportsNet LA). When he crossed home on Brenton Doyle's walk-off sacrifice fly win over the Dodgers, he greeted umpire Lance Barksdale whose ears were likely still ringing from the screams Cave dealt him Tuesday.\n\nColorado followed up its heartbreaking loss with a 7-6 tally Wednesday to set up a possible series split with the Dodgers if it can come through again Thursday.\n\nRockies manager Bud Black said before the game that the previous day's results weren't their concern. He said good or bad, he and his team need to wipe the results.\n\nOn Tuesday, Colorado was dealt a tough blow when Barksdale called a checked swing a ball and left Victor Vodnik without a third out. Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez hit a three-run, go-ahead homer soon after that doomed the club to another loss to its division rival.\n\nIt was the sixth time this season that the Rockies entered the ninth inning with a lead and allowed five or more runs to lose it. No team in the Modern Era has done more in a season, and the year has months to go.\n\nBlack wanted to see his team respond to the adversity by learning from it but forgetting it. When the Rockies jumped out to a 3-0 lead Wednesday, it looked like they had done just that.\n\nShohei Ohtani's three-run double in the second inning was a swift reminder of how a game can change within minutes, just as Tuesday's loss did.\n\nThe Dodgers dealt another blow in the fifth when they went up 6-4 and looked primed for a possible sweep. A term that circles around the Rockies clubhouse is \"push back.\"\n\nCave's single, Elehuris Montero's single and Doyle's eventual sacrifice fly in the ninth inning were their push.\n\nSign Up for Pikes Peak 5 Game analysis and insights from The Gazette sports staff including columns by Woody Paige and Paul Klee.\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. Success! Thank you for subscribing to our newsletter. View all of our newsletters. Featured Local Savings\n\n\"Baseball is kind of poetic sometimes,\" Cave said. \"I think it shows that records can show some things, but you when you watch us go out there against a really good team and string good at-bats together... it's the sign of a really good team.\"\n\nAdael Amador's effort came after a foul bunt attempt. A quick mound meeting allowed Black to call it off and let him swing -- the No. 1 prospect grounded out to the right side to advance Cave to third before Doyle drove him in.\n\nAs much as the Rockies want to wipe previous results, replicating winning ones would be a welcome change.\n\nThey haven't won back-to-back games since May 29 and 31 against Cleveland and the Dodgers. In the team's first 74 games, it's only won multiple games in a row three times -- one of the stretches came during Colorado's seven-game win streak. The other two streaks only lasted two games.\n\nThe Rockies have a chance to change that on Thursday.\n\nRockies 7, Dodgers 6\n\nWhat happened: Colorado battled back and forth with Los Angeles until Brenton Doyle's walk-off sacrifice fly scored Jake Cave and completed the Rockies' comeback from a 6-4 deficit.\n\nOn the mound: Ryan Feltner dealt with trouble but worked five innings. He allowed six earned runs -- four in the second inning -- on seven hits and two walks. He also struck out six.
