The 476-foot blast was the longest home run in the MLB this season.\n\nTrailing 7-2 at the time of that blast, it sparked a come-from-behind effort as Los Angeles prevailed 11-9 against a division rival.\n\nThe moonshot might've been aided a bit by that thin Denver air, but there's no doubt it was an absolute bomb - no matter the location.\n\nThe homer came in the top of the sixth inning with LA down by five runs. Facing Colorado lefty Austin Gomber with a 2-0 count and nobody on, Ohtani awaited his pitch and locked in when he saw the 84 MPH delivery.\n\nHe quickly turned on the off-speed pitch and sent it sailing to the deepest part of the ballpark.\n\nAfter the game, Gomber could do nothing but praise his opponent.\n\n\"I thought I pitched him well the first two at-bats... He's the best player on the planet and I just made a mistake slider down the middle. You're not gonna get those past him.\"\n\nThough he'd like to have the mistake back, Gomber pitched well enough to win. The starter exited the game with his team up 8-4 in the seventh frame.\n\nUnfortunately, the bullpen would let that victory slip away.\n\nLos Angeles loaded the bases with one out in their final at-bat before Jason Heyward blasted a pinch-hit grand slam to cut a 9-4 deficit to just a run.\n\nThe Dodgers would later get another pair on while Colorado put one more away to give Teoscar Hernandez a chance to tie or win with two outs.\n\nThe Rockies believed they'd secured the final out of the ball game when Hernandez unsuccessfully attempted to check his swing. Umpires ruled that he didn't cross the plane, but replay showed that he did!\n\nHaving new life, the slugger belted a three-run homer on the very next pitch to give his team the lead.\n\nThe Colorado bench exploded after the bomb, claiming they'd been stripped of a win. Los Angeles would record the final three outs in the bottom of the ninth to escape with a two-run victory.\n\nWere the Rockies robbed? There's certainly a case to be made!\n\nStill, the bullpen deserves some blame for the three walks and three hits allowed prior to that dagger. {"uri": "8186261256", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:36:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:36:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T03:35:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.latimes.com/sports/dodgers/story/2024-06-19/dodgers-colorado-rockies-recap-mlb", "title": "Shoe is on the other foot as Dodgers lose to Rockies in walk-off fashion", "body": "This time, the late-game magic belonged to the Colorado Rockies.\n\nA day after the Dodgers' historic ninth-inning comeback at Coors Field, their hosts answered back Wednesday with an 7-6 walk-off win.\n\nWith the score tied in the bottom of the ninth -- and one of the Dodgers' typically low-leverage relievers, Yohan Ram\u00edrez, on the mound in the most crucial of situations -- the Rockies flipped the script from Tuesday's night loss, when they blew a five-run lead in the final frame.\n\nThis time, they put two runners aboard immediately with back-to-back singles. They advanced the lead one to third on a ground ball to first base.\n\nThen, in a rare celebratory sequence for a team that has long resided in the National League West basement, outfielder Brenton Doyle delivered a walk-off sacrifice fly.\n\nThe Rockies piled out of the dugout. They sprayed Gatorade around the infield.\n\nThe exaltation the Dodgers experienced Tuesday, this time was on the other side.\n\nThe Dodgers had led for most of the game, despite a rocky start from right-hander Bobby Miller.\n\nMaking his first outing in more than two months because of a shoulder injury, Miller battled through a five-run, 6 \u2153-inning appearance. He gave up a three-run homer to Michael Toglia in the bottom of the first, after issuing a single and walk with two out in the inning.\n\nBut the 25-year-old bounced back from there, giving up just one run over the next five innings with the help of three double plays.\n\nThe Dodgers, meanwhile, surged ahead thanks to production from the bottom of the lineup.\n\nIn the second inning, Nos. 6-8 hitters Gavin Lux (single), Cavan Biggio (hit-by-pitch) and Kik\u00e9 Hern\u00e1ndez (walk) loaded the bases for Shohei Ohtani, who promptly unloaded them with a three-run double. Ohtani was driven home on Freddie Freeman's RBI single in the next at-bat.\n\nWith the score tied again, 4-4, in the top of the fifth, it was another bottom-half hitter, outfielder Jason Heyward from the five-hole, who delivered a two-run double off the wall in right field, continuing his recent tear after Tuesday night's ninth-inning grand slam.\n\nIn the top of the seventh, though, Roberts tried to extend Miller -- who was only at 73 pitches -- only to watch him surrender a leadoff double to Sean Bouchard, who eventually scored what was Miller's fifth earned run of the game.\n\nAfter Miller exited, the seventh only got messier for the Dodgers. Third baseman Biggio booted a grounder with one out. No. 9 hitter Adael Amador belted a double off reliever Daniel Hudson. Hernandez took a half-swing at a 1-2 fastball, but first base umpire Lance Barksdale ruled that Hernandez did not commit. Colorado manager Bud Black argued the call and was ejected.\n\nOn the next pitch, Hernandez hit his 18th home to make it 11-9. After Hernandez's ball cleared the wall, Colorado right field Jake Cave immediately took a few steps toward Barksdale and began yelling. Rockies' second baseman Alan Trejo stepped between Cave and Barksdale after the inning ended.\n\nEvan Phillips got the only batter he faced, Hunter Goodman, to recorded his 11th save in as many chances. Cave, the on-deck hitter, was restrained by bench Mike Redmond as he attempted to reach Bardsdale.\n\nElehuris Montero and Brenton Doyle homered for the Rockies, who scored four runs in the first and twice led by five runs.\n\nDoyle added three singles for his first career four-hit game, scored twice, and made a diving catch of Ohtani's line drive to right-center field with runners on first and second and two outs in the seventh inning, preserving an 8-4 lead.\n\nDodgers starter Walker Buehler gave up eight hits and seven runs in four innings. It was the first time the 29-yeaer-old right-hander allowed more than three earned runs since returning to the rotation May 6 after missing the 2023 season because of Tommy John surgery. He struck out two and walked one.\n\nMichael Petersen (1-0) worked two innings of relief and struck out two for the win.\n\nTRAINER'S ROOM\n\nDodgers: LHP Clayton Kershaw (shoulder surgery) is scheduled to pitch three innings for Class A Rancho Cucamonga on Wednesday in his first rehab start of the season. \"He's doing fantastic,\" manager Dave Roberts said, adding that Kershaw will follow the natural progression of two or three more rehab starts \"and then we'll see where we are at.\"\n\nRockies: DH/OF Charlie Blackmon (right hamstring tightness) was removed after suffering his injury while running the bases in the first. ... LHP Kyle Freeland (elbow strain) gave up two hits and two runs and struck out four in four innings of a rehab start for Triple-A Albuquerque on Tuesday and appears close to returning. ... 2B Brendan Rodgers (hamstring) did normal pregame work Tuesday and is expected to begin a rehab assignment on Thursday with an eye toward a weekend activation. ... {"uri": "8182894484", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "04:28:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T04:28:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T04:27:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/mlb/los-angeles-dodgers/news/james-paxton-steps-strong-start-after-yoshinobu-yamamoto-injury/06d493acfc2c904d58d8a1a4", "title": "James Paxton steps up with strong start after Yoshinobu Yamamoto injury", "body": "Despite a comfortable division lead and the National League's best run differential, Monday felt like something of a must-win for the Los Angeles Dodgers. If anything, they needed the morale boost given injuries to Yoshinobu Yamamoto, Mookie Betts, and others over the weekend.\n\nWhile the offense came through in the 9-5 victory, it was the start from James Paxton that ended up almost being the most noteworthy component of the series opener in Colorado. Paxton had, of course, already bounced back from a miserable 1.2 inning, six earned run start against Pittsburgh back on June 5th. He threw six innings of one run ball against Texas last week. But Monday showed us a version of Paxton we hadn't seen in some time.\n\nThe final line for the southpaw read seven innings, a pair of hits, one walk, and just one earned run. It was his longest outing in a Dodgers uniform, but also represented his highest strikeout total. Paxton punched out eight Rockies hitters, giving him his highest strikeout figure since June of last year when he was pitching for the Red Sox.\n\nIn that regard, Monday's start was quite the deviation from the Dodgers version of James Paxton. While he's never been a truly overpowering arm, he's been even more extremely contact-oriented since joining Los Angeles. His 13.8 K% represents the lowest rate of his career, with his previous low mark coming all the way back in 2015. His success this year has, instead, come largely on his ability to limit quality contact.\n\nMonday's Paxton was all about the punchout, though. Eight strikeouts actually exceeds his total from his last three starts combined. His previous high since signing with the Dodgers was five, back on April 1st.\n\nWithin his eight strikeouts, Paxton went for a Whiff% of 29 across his three pitch types. He was particularly effective with the knuckle curve, with which he generated whiffs at a 47 percent clip. Rockies hitters were chasing at a 29 percent rate, including a 43 percent mark against the breaking pitch. For the year, Paxton had posted a chase rate of 26.2 percent & a whiff rate of just 7.4 percent prior to Monday's start.\n\nVelocity was in line with what we've seen this year (93.3 MPH average vs. 93.4 average on the year), but he had spin rates up on both the knuckle curve & changeup, according to Baseball Savant. Both the fastball & change each featured more break as a result. He simply had it all working.\n\nAt the same time, this is obviously a Rockies team prone to the K. As a team, they chase more than anybody outside of Miami and feature a strikeout rate that trails only Seattle & Boston. It's important to at least acknowledge that context within a larger theoretical hope of sustaining some rediscovered strikeout ability.\n\nNonetheless, getting a glimpse of a more vintage flavor of {"uri": "8185375405", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:17:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:17:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:16:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/06/19/sports/rockies-incensed-by-umpires-blown-call-in-meltdown-against-dodgers/", "title": "Rockies incensed by umpire's blown call in epic meltdown against...", "body": "Rockies players, manager Bud Black and members of the team's broadcasting crew were outraged after a blown check-swing call Tuesday night led to a go-ahead three-run homer by the Dodgers' Teoscar Hernandez in an epic Colorado meltdown in their 11-9 home loss.\n\nThe Rockies seemingly had the game won when Hernandez appeared to swing on a 1-2 pitch, only for veteran umpire Lance Barksdale to rule he checked his swing.\n\nHernandez homered on the next offering to complete the Dodgers' rally from a 9-4 deficit in the ninth.\n\n\"I saw a swing -- check-swing, but I thought he went,\" said Black, per MLB.com, who was ejected after erupting at the missed call.\n\nThe Rockies are not without blame for coughing up a five-run lead in the ninth, even holding a 99 percent chance to win with one out in the inning, per Statcast, but they appeared to get hosed Tuesday night.\n\nThe Dodgers trailed 9-8 and had two on with two outs for Hernandez when reliever Victor Vodnik threw an elevated 99.9-mph fastball that induced a check-swing, with Hernandez seeming to commit to the pitch.\n\nHome plate umpire Will Little checked with Barksdale, the first base umpire, who ruled Hernandez held on the 1-2 offering, shocking most non-Dodgers viewers.\n\n\"He went,\" Rockies announcer Drew Goodman said. \"Oh, man. Lance Barksdale said no.\"\n\nBlack screamed at Barksdale after the pitch, and while we're not professional lip readers, it would appear he screamed \"F-king bulls-t\" at the veteran umpire.\n\nThat earned the manager an ejection.\n\nAs fate would have it, the next pitch, a 100.6-mph heater in the heart of the zone, landed in the Rockes' bullpen in right-center to give the Dodgers a stunning lead.\n\nGoodman could not believe the timeline of events.\n\n\"The 2-2, in the air, deep right-center and this one is gone. You got to be kidding me!\" Goodman said. \"From a strikeout to a three-run homer.\"\n\nRockies right fielder Jake Cave immediately turned and pointed at Barksdale after the homer, showing frustration with the non-strikeout.\n\nCave reportedly had to be restrained later by a teammate.\n\n\"I was yelling at [Barksdale] from right during the inning,\" Cave said, according to MLB.com. \"But then we made the last out and I'm coming in. And he looks me right in the face and goes, 'Cave, it's not even close.' That's when I really got [upset].\"\n\nThe Rockies put a man on in the ninth but couldn't match the Dodgers' heroics, suffering one of the worst losses of the season by any team.\n\nAll because of a Watching this game and, particularly, how both offenses fared against the opposing team's starter, you got the feeling of a blowout. In the end, that wasn't quite the case, and knowing it was Colorado, things got a bit dicey late.\n\nLA seemed to be crushing anything Ty Blach threw out there, with three homers off the lefty, coincidentally the same number of hard-hit balls Gavin Stone allowed in his whole outing. However, by the time both starters' outings were finished, the Dodgers lead was only 5-2.\n\nIt seems odd to say this, but five runs felt like too little off a starter who allowed 10 hits and saw a minimum of five batters per frame across his four innings, giving up three home runs. The scoring began rather early with a Shohei Ohtani leadoff bomb, continuing a massive series for the Dodgers DH who reached multiple times in each of the four games in Coors.\n\nIn the fourth inning, after hitting roughly eighteen balls to the warning track in this series, Will Smith finally got one over the fence and Freddie Freeman made it back-to-back bombs, both hitting their 11th on the year.\n\nEarly in the broadcast, in a somewhat hyperbolic fashion, Eric Karros deemed Gavin Stone as the most consistent starter for the Dodgers in 2024. And while that might be a bit of a stretch, the young righty is certainly even building a case for the All-Star Game.\n\nFacing a challenge he had yet to encounter in his short big-league career, Stone not only survived Coors Field, but thrived in it. No Rockies' hitter came around to score while Stone was on the mound.\n\nMissing barrels was the name of the game for Stone, who had both the heater and changeup working perfectly, entering the sixth in great shape as the Dodgers led 5-0. Unfortunately, things got a bit trickier in Stone's final frame, as he left with the bases loaded after two walks in the frame. Dave Roberts called on Blake Treinen to be his fireman, and at the very least he somewhat minimized the damage, allowing a two-run single, but proceeding to strike out the hero of the previous game Brenton Doyle.\n\nEven more than the final line, you can get a good glimpse of how dominant Stone was for much of this one as he managed 16 whiffs at Coors Field, showcasing good command and swing-and-miss stuff. His seven strikeouts matched a career high.\n\nTreinen, Daniel Hudson, Alex Vesia, and Evan Philips followed Stone to wrap this one up with kudos to Vesia. The Dodgers' southpaw reliever took a blow, allowing a lefty-on-lefty bomb to the first year he faced, but went on to strike out the next three batters to finish off the eighth inning.\n\nIt'll be an unusual weekend at home as the Dodgers return to Chavez Ravine for a two-game set with the Angels, which means the rare Sunday off-day. The Dodgers haven't yet named a starting pitcher yet for Friday (7:10 p.m.; SportsNet LA, MLB Network), but Dave Roberts told reporters before Thursday's game that Landon Knack and Ryan Yarbrough are possibilities to pitch Friday, or with three off days coming in short order, a bullpen game is also possible. {"uri": "8187312322", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:36:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:36:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:35:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4745098054409027, "url": "https://dodgerblue.com/teoscar-hernandez-removed-early-dodgers-game-nothing-serious/2024/06/20/", "title": "Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez Removed Early From Dodgers' Loss: 'Nothing Serious'", "body": "Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez has been a key member of the Los Angeles Dodgers lineup this season, and his importance to the team was most recently on display during a furious rally in the ninth inning on Tuesday night.\n\nBut that was followed by the right-handed slugger going just 1-for-4 in the Dodgers' walk-off loss. Hern\u00e1ndez would have received another opportunity to potentially put his imprint on the game if not being removed early.\n\nChris Taylor replaced Hern\u00e1ndez in left field to begin the bottom of the seventh inning and lined out to second base in his only at-bat.\n\nFollowing the loss, Hern\u00e1ndez explained he was merely taken out for rest purposes, as seen on SportsNet LA:\n\n\"Everything is fine, yeah. ... Just being safe. Just to get some rest. I'm going to be in there [Thursday].\"\n\nThe Dodgers only held a 6-4 lead at the time Hern\u00e1ndez was removed from the game, which occurred after he grounded out to end the top of the seventh. Despite the close score and ultimate loss, Hern\u00e1ndez said he was not surprised by Dodgers manager Dave Roberts taking him out:\n\n\"No, because he has done it before. It's nothing new. Nothing to think about. He's done it before. It was one of those situations where he wanted to get C.T. an at-bat. He always does it when he's going to play him tomorrow. It's nothing serious.\"\n\nHern\u00e1ndez did acknowledge playing at Coors Field for the first time in his career has proven somewhat challenging because of the high altitude:\n\n\"It's a little hard. This is my first time here playing regular games. You can feel the difference when you run a lot, or go first to third. But it's been fine. I just adjust to it, try to get some rest and keep going.\"\n\nThrough the first three games of the series, Hern\u00e1ndez is 3-for-14 with one double, one home run and three RBI.\n\nOverall, he's started in each of the Dodgers' 76 games this season. That's going to be 77 when Hern\u00e1ndez is in the Dodgers lineup for the series finale against the Rockies.\n\nFreddie Freeman is tied with Hern\u00e1ndez for the team lead in games played and Vodnik was just one strike away from ending the game and giving his team a 9-8 win.\n\nWith the 1-2 pitch, Vodnik through a high fastball that was way above the zone. Still, Hernandez began to swing before trying to pull back and check his swing. The crowd at Coors Field immediately cheered as fans assumed Hernandez swung and the game was over. Instead, the home plate umpire appealed to the umpire at first base, who ruled it a checked swing. As a result, the pitch was a ball and the count became 2-2.\n\nA replay of the swing showed Hernandez's bat clearly going past home plate.\n\n\"He just got robbed,\" play-by-play announcer Drew Goodman said.\n\nRockies manager Bud Black immediately left the dugout to scream at the first base umpire. Freeman did some light jogging down the line before remaining in the game.\n\nFollowing the Dodgers' win, Freeman explained he merely was out of breath after the play, as seen on SportsNet LA:\n\n\"That was just the ground moving on me. I gave everything I had in my oxygen tank to beat that ball out. Four games in Denver, a couple hot ones, it was a sneaky hot game today. I guess I didn't have much left in there, and I had to beat that ball out. I'm OK. I just needed a little hug from Clayton.\"\n\nThe first indication that Freeman avoided injury was not being removed, and he also ran normally when breaking up a potential double play. {"uri": "8184722934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:51:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:51:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:51:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.denverpost.com/2024/06/18/jake-cave-umpire-lance-barkdales-missed-strike-three-call-costs-rockies-a-win-over-dodgers/", "title": "Jake Cave: Umpire Lance Barkdale's missed strike-three call costs Rockies a win over Dodgers", "body": "Not on the field or in the clubhouse after the Rockies suffered an 11-9, kick-in-the-crotch loss to the Dodgers Tuesday night at Coors Field.\n\nColorado entered the ninth inning leading 9-4, but Jason Heyward hit a pinch-hit grand slam off of closer Tyler Kinley. Then Teoscar Hernandez blasted a three-run homer off Victor Vodnik to win the game for the Dodgers.\n\nHowever, the Rockies were sure that Hernandez struck out. One pitch before his homer, he took a swing at Vodnik's 1-2, 98 mph fastball. The Rockies appealed to first base umpire Lance Barksdale, looking for strike three, but Barksdale ruled that Hernandez did not commit to the swing.\n\nRockies manager Bud Black vehemently argued the call and was ejected.\n\nOn the next pitch, Hernandez hit his 18th home to make it 11-9.\n\n\"It was close,\" Hernandez said of his swing. \"You can call it either way and it will be fine. When Jason hit the grand slam ... you knew something was going to happen. I just wanted to get a good pitch hit to tie the game. I put a little extra and it went over the fence. I knew as soon as I hit. It was great, especially because it put the team ahead.\"\n\nBlack was positive that Hernandez had struck out.\n\n\"I saw a swing -- a check swing -- but I thought he went (around),\" said Black, who was ejected for the second time this season and the 12th time in his eight-year career with the Rockies.\n\nBlack wasn't the only one from the Rockies' side who went ballistic. So did Cave, who and had to be restrained from going after Barksdale on the field.\n\n\"Everybody has seen (the swing) now, and I had a good view from right field,\" Cave said. \"In real time, I didn't think it was close. ... Then, after we made the last out, as I was running in (to the dugout), Lance looks me right in the face and said, 'Cave, it's not even close.'\n\n\"That's when I really got (ticked off) because, it was like, 'Are you really that out of tune with the game that you can tell me that it's not even close?' Everybody in the world can see that it was at least close. And (Hernandez) did swing.\n\n\"That's one of the best teams in baseball, and we are beating them, and our pitchers are out there grinding. ... That game's won. On a swing and miss, that game's won, and we beat the Los Angeles Dodgers.\"\n\nBlack said he \"was fine\" with Cave's emotional outburst on the field.\n\n\"Every player has to be himself,\" Black said. \"Jake plays with a lot of passion and there is a high level of caring, even for the short time he's been a Rockie. He's a major-league player with a great deal of competitive fire. That's who he is.\n\n\"He was upset, and that's fine with me. He wasn't the only guy who was upset, and he showed it. Which is fine by me. This is an emotional game ... and we get into it. And tonight, Jake Cave, amongst other guys, got into it. {"uri": "8183549606", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "12:05:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T12:05:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T12:04:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://www.truebluela.com/2024/6/18/24180744/freddie-freeman-dodgers-walk-record-june-hot-streak", "title": "Freddie Freeman ties Dodgers walk record, continues scorching June", "body": "The Dodgers in their first game this season without Mookie Betts on the active roster went with a volume approach, reaching base in every inning to score nine runs to beat the Rockies.\n\nLA reached base 23 times, with 14 hits, eight walks, and a hit by pitch, which helped them score in five of nine innings.\n\n\"Obviously you're never going to replace Mookie Betts, he's a top-five player in all of Major League Baseball,\" Freddie Freeman told reporters at Coors Field after the game, as shown on SportsNet LA. \"But we've got a lot of good guys in this group, a lot of veteran guys. A lot of us have been on teams that have lost people to injuries, but we've got a good group to hold it down. Let them get healthy, and we'll welcome him back here sooner rather than later.\"\n\nFreeman batted six times on Monday and reached base all six times. That included walking five times to tie a Dodgers record. All those walks came in his first five trips to the plate, the last one an intentional free pass after Shohei Ohtani advanced to third base with only one out and a 2-0 count on Freeman.\n\nThe Dodgers scored twice in the ninth inning, which allowed Freeman to bat a sixth time. He took two balls in this final trip to the plate, but his sixth walk never came. Instead, Freeman singled. He scored twice on the night, giving him a box score batting line of 1 2 1 0 5, with the latter number his walk total.\n\nOnly one other player in major league history, at least dating back to 1901, had a game with that exact batting line. It was Carl Yastrzemski, on May 25, 1971 for the Red Sox against the Senators, but his final walk came in the 11th inning. Freeman is the only player ever with a 1 2 1 0 5 line in a nine-inning game.\n\nGreg Brock on May 17, 1983 at Montreal: This game needed 15 innings to decide, with the Expos winning against Steve Howe. Brock was 0-for-2, and only two of his walks came in the first nine innings. He walked again in the 11th inning, then was intentionally walked in the 13th and 15th innings, both times with a runner in scoring position.\n\nMax Muncy on April 25, 2021 vs. Padres: This was the same night as the Oscars, which was only a few miles away at Union Station, in a game during which the Dodgers bullpen gave away a 7-1 lead. Muncy's fifth walk was intentional, in the 10th inning.\n\nThat leaves two other Dodgers to walk five times in a game that lasted a regular nine innings.\n\nGene Hermanski on September 22, 1949 at the Cardinals: The Brooklyn left fielder had a busy night. He singled home the Dodgers' first two runs of the night in what was a 19-6 rout in St. Louis. The second of his walks, in the fourth inning, came with the bases loaded, giving Hermanski a three-RBI game. Hermanski's fifth-inning was intentional, with first base open and two outs in what at the time was an 8-1 game. The problem was Gil Hodges batted next, and he singled home two runs.\n\nDusty Baker on September 28, 1980 at the Padres: Baker is the only Dodger with five unintentional walks in a game. He did so in a pennant race in San Diego, with the Dodgers vying to catch Houston in the season's final week. LA lost this game, but Baker did his best, reaching base in all five trips to the plate. He never batted with anyone on base all day.\n\nFreeman's single and five walks on Monday in Colorado continued his red-hot June. He's reached base in all 15 games this month, with at least one hit in 14 of those games. Freeman in June is hitting .373/.500/.725 with four home runs, four doubles, a triple, 10 RBI, and 15 runs scored.\n\nWith 46 walks through the Dodgers' first 74 games, Freeman is on pace for 100 walks on the season. His career high is 90 walks, in 2014 with Atlanta. Freeman has also walked 80 or more four other times, including 84 walks in 2022 with the Dodgers.", "source": {"uri": "truebluela.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "True Blue LA"}, "authors": {"uri": "8185839843", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:10:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:10:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:09:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://dodgersnation.com/dave-roberts-compares-teoscar-hernandez-to-former-dodgers-fan-favorite/2024/06/19/", "title": "Dave Roberts Compares Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez to Former Dodgers Fan Favorite", "body": "The Los Angeles Dodgers participated in arguably the game of the year thus far when they mounted a comeback from five runs down in the ninth inning to win Tuesday's matchup against the Colorado Rockies, 11-9. The game looked out of reach for the Dodgers, but great at-bats, solid contact, and some luck involved got the Dodgers over the top.\n\nThe guys scratched and clawed, but the hero of the game was Dodgers outfielder and likely All-Star Teoscar Hern\u00e1ndez. Hern\u00e1ndez came up clutch for the Dodgers, which isn't new or a surprise if you're familiar with his brief tenure in Dodger blue.\n\nWith two on, two outs in the ninth inning, and down by one run, Hern\u00e1ndez hit a three-run blast to give L.A. the lead and ultimately the win. After the game, manager Dave Roberts spoke to the media, including Jack Harris of the Los Angeles Times, and compared Hern\u00e1ndez to a fan favorite and slugger, Manny Ramirez.\n\n\"He reminds me of Manny Ramirez. When guys are on base, that's when he really starts to lock it in and focus. He hunts those RBIs. That's how you win baseball games.\"\n\nRamirez, especially with the Dodgers, always came through when it mattered most. Ramirez had 53 RBIs in 53 games after being traded to the Dodgers midway through the 2008 season. Hern\u00e1ndez leads the Dodgers with 54 RBIs -- a 117-RBI pace for the season.\n\nHern\u00e1ndez's home run didn't come without controversy, though. On a 2-and-2 count, he was almost called for a game-ending check swing. Luckily, the first base umpire, Lance Barksdale, ruled the pitch a ball, keeping the at-bat alive. On the very next pitch, Hern\u00e1ndez took advantage of the opportunity and crushed one deep to right-center field.\n\n\"It was close. Now that I saw the replay, I don't think so. But you could've called it either way, and I think it would've been fine.\n\nHern\u00e1ndez, like Ramirez, brings a tenacity to the baseball field that L.A. has lacked for some time. It's a kid's game, and Hern\u00e1ndez does his best to show emotion and get his teammates hyped when needed. Tuesday's match was just that.\n\nPhoto Credit: Vincent Carchietta-USA TODAY Sports\n\nHave you subscribed to our YouTube channel? Then, Jason Heyward clipped the right-field foul pole for a grand slam.\n\nShohei Ohtani followed with a base hit. He then advanced to second on a wild pitch. {"uri": "8187701406", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "21:00:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T21:00:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:59:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.ocregister.com/2024/06/20/ohtani-will-face-former-angels-teammates-in-first-regular-season-game-since-his-free-agency/", "title": "Ohtani will face former Angels teammates in first regular season game since his free agency", "body": "DENVER - The day has come when Shohei Ohtani faces his former Angels team. If he's excited or anxious about it, he's keeping it to himself. More than likely, he just wants to get it over with.\n\nTake it from Dodgers manager Dave Roberts, who recalled that's the way he felt whenever he went against a former club during his lengthy playing career.\n\n\"I think he's worried about today and once tomorrow comes, tomorrow comes,\" Roberts said Thursday ahead of the Dodgers series finale at Colorado. \"I think that he is grateful for his time in Anaheim, grateful for the fans. And I think he just wants to help the Dodgers win, but I think he wants to get it over with.\"\n\nThe Dodgers return home Friday to begin a two-game series against the Angels, where Ohtani emerged as a pitching and hitting superstar in six years with the team. He joined the Dodgers in the offseason, agreeing to a $700 million free-agent contract, though he won't pitch this season while continuing to recover from an injured elbow ligament.\n\nOhtani acknowledged \"looking forward\" to playing them and added that he still follows the Angels \"here and there\" to keep up with what he called the regular news.\n\nSpeaking through an interpreter following Wednesday night's game, Ohtani also said the vibe surrounding his upcoming appearance against the Angels doesn't feel all that different from any other game he's played or will play with his new team because it is not in Anaheim.\n\n\"I believe more so when I go to Anaheim (it will be emotional for him),\" Ohtani said. \"But since we're playing at Dodgers Stadium, I'm just going to be focused on playing the game.\"\n\nThe Dodgers have not yet announced a starter for Friday night's game against the Angels. Roberts said the team is still weighing its options in coming up with a replacement for injured Yoshinobu Yamamoto.\n\n\"We are either going to do a bullpen game or do a spot start,\" Roberts said. \"I don't know if there's going to be somebody from Triple A.\"\n\nIf they do opt to bring up a starter from the minors, Landan Knack is a possibility. He is 3-2 with a 3.54 ERA for Triple A Oklahoma City. Knack made four starts for the Dodgers early in the season, going 1-1 with a 2.61 ERA.\n\nRookie center fielder Andy Pages has become a fixture in the Dodgers lineup in relatively short order.\n\nPages made his major league debut April 16 against Washington after being called up from Triple A Oklahoma City to fill in for Jason Heyward, who missed time with a back problem.\n\nHeading into Thursday's game at Colorado, Pages was hitting .266, scoring 35 runs on 55 hits, including eight home runs and he has played exceptional defense.\n\nRoberts said he was surprised how quickly Pages has made adjustments.\n\n\"Yes. Pleasantly surprised, because it is not easy. He's a very smart player. He lives and breathes baseball. He's got a high baseball IQ. He's not afraid to work. And he doesn't run from big spots, where certain players do. He fought, he fought when he was scuffling (earlier). He continued to work, remained confident, fought in the batter's box and competed.
